title: Extending Grace
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy, the town clockmaker, possessed hands that seemed to hold time itself. Not only could he coax intricate gears into harmonious rhythm, but he also had a way of extending grace, like offering a complimentary cleaning to a customer who could barely afford to repair their grandmother's mantel clock. One sweltering August afternoon, a young boy named Timmy shuffled into the shop, clutching a broken pocket watch. Timmy explained, with tear-filled eyes, that it was his grandfather's, a treasured memento. Mr. Abernathy examined the watch, his brow furrowing slightly. The mechanism was severely damaged, and replacing the parts would be costly.

Timmy hung his head, resigned to the loss. But then, Mr. Abernathy's eyes twinkled. He said, 'Timmy, I can't promise I can fix it perfectly, but I can promise to do my best. And seeing as it means so much to you, we'll consider the labor a 'learning opportunity' for me.' Timmy's face lit up. For weeks, the boy visited the shop, watching Mr. Abernathy meticulously work on the watch. The clockmaker patiently explained the intricacies of each gear and spring. Eventually, the watch ticked again, not perfectly, but it ticked. The imperfections added to its unique story.

Mr. Abernathy had not only restored a timepiece but also offered a lesson in the boundless nature of grace. It wasn't just about fixing something broken; it was about recognizing the value of the person standing before him and extending kindness beyond what was required or expected. It was the gracious act that left a far more lasting impact than the repair itself. Just like Mr. Abernathy, we are called to look past the outward appearance and circumstances and extend grace to those around us, offering not just solutions but also understanding, compassion, and a helping hand. Grace, freely given, reflects the very heart of God.
image_description: A close-up of aged clock gears, catching the light, with an open clockmaker's kit filled with tiny tools subtly blurred in the background.
insights: The concept of grace is central to the Christian faith. Ephesians 2:8-9 states, 'For it is by grace you have been saved, through faith—and this is not from yourselves, it is the gift of God—not by works, so that no one can boast.' This highlights that salvation is not earned but is a free gift offered by God. Furthermore, Colossians 3:13 encourages believers to, 'Bear with each other and forgive one another if any of you has a grievance against someone. Forgive as the Lord forgave you,' emphasizing the importance of extending grace within our communities and relationships.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank You for the immeasurable gift of Your grace. Help me to recognize the opportunities to extend that grace to others, just as You have so freely given it to me. Open my eyes to see beyond outward appearances and circumstances, and fill my heart with compassion and understanding. Give me the wisdom to offer kindness and support to those in need, reflecting Your love in all that I do. In Jesus’ name, Amen.
reflection: Think about a time someone extended grace to you. How did it make you feel? How can you be more intentional about extending grace to others in your daily life, especially to those who may seem undeserving or difficult to love?
